post.description:
This endpoint promotes and confirms a ghost user. The user must supply a promotion code obtained from a call to the PUT variant of this endpoint.

If only_check is true, this endpoint only checks the validity of the promotion code, and does not perform any mutations.

parameters.name: email

parameters.description: A promotion code returned by a call to the PUT variant of this endpoint.
parameters.name: promotion_code

parameters.description: The password for the new user. This password must meet the requirements described in the documentation for POST /accounts/passwords. Required if **only_check** is false.
parameters.name: password

parameters.description: Required if **only_check is false.
parameters.name: metadata

parameters.description: If true, only check the validatiy of the promotion code.
parameters.name: only_check

parameters.name: client_id

parameters.description: Device ID of the device making the request. This must be included for a parley token to be included in the response.

put.description:
This endpoint initiates the reset password flow. It triggers a confirmation email to the user with a confirmation code. This code must be submitted to  the POST variant to perform the reset itself. The code expires, but clients must not make assumptions regarding how long the code will remain valid  before it does.

This endpoint is rate limited per user. If a user exceeds the number of  allowed requests, the request will fail and the user's ability to reset their  password will be locked for a period of time. The client must not make assumptions about the number of allowed requests, duration of the lock, or time period over which the requests are counted. 

No email is sent when a 4XX error is returned.

parameters.description: The email address of the account desiring a password reset
parameters.name: email

403.description:
Possible messages:
- **access_denied**: no user corresponds to the provided email
- **invalid_code**: the confirmation code has already been used

400.description:
Possible messages:
- **invalid_request**: 
  - invalid request body
  - invalid email address
  - invalid or expired confirmation code
- **invalid_password_format**:
  - invalid password format

post.description:
This endpoint finishes the reset password flow and performs the password change. The caller must supply a not-expired cofirmation code that was sent to the user by the PUT variant of this endpoint.  This code may be used only once.

A user's password must be valid according to the following requirements:
- Length of at least 8 characters and at most 50 characters
- Must not be all numbers.
- Must not be on a server-stored list of the most obvious passwords. Clients must not make assumptions
  regarding the contents of this list.
- The string "upthere" is case-insensitively ignored in the string when checking validity. 

If the only_check parameter is set to true, this endpoint checks the password's validity only. It does not require a confirmation code, and does not make any changes. 

If only_check is false and this endpoint returns success, it will perform the following actions in addition to  changing the user's password:
- Invalidate all of the user's refresh tokens
- Unlock the rate limiter used by the POST /accounts/tokens endpoint
- Clear the user's token cookies, if the client is a web client

parameters.description: The email address of the user whose password should be reset.
parameters.name: email

parameters.description: The confirmation code sent to the user after a call to PUT variant of this endpoint. Required unless only_check is true. This code must not be expired and must not have already been used.
parameters.name: reset_code

parameters.description: The new password to set for the user. This password must satsify the requirements listed in this endpoint's description.
parameters.name: new_password

parameters.description: If this is set to true, this endpoint checks the password's validity only and does not make any changes.
parameters.name: only_check

post.description:
This endpoint creates users for testing. Users created by this endpoint are confirmed automatically and do not require a second request.

Users created by this endpoint must have an email of the form uptheretest+<value>@upthere.com. Additionally, a secret must be supplied in the X-Upthere-TestCode header.

parameters.description: Secret authorizing the request. If you do not know what the secret is, it's doing its job well.
parameters.name: X-Upthere-TestCode

parameters.description: The email address of the user to create. Must have the form uptheretest+<value>@upthere.com
parameters.name: email

parameters.description: The password for the new user. This password must meet the requirements described in the documentation for POST /accounts/passwords.
parameters.name: password

parameters.description: The cluster at which the user should be created. This is an optional parameter and if not specified the user will be allocated at the local cluster
parameters.name: cluster

secret.description: Secret used to configure an authenticator app. This is the same secret returned in the uri, but allows the user to enter the secret into the authenticator app manually. Present only when setting up an authenticator app.

put.description:
This endpoint initiates the 2FA setup flow. This endpoint on its own does not make any changes to the user's account. The server returns a state token to be passed to the POST variant to complete 2FA setup. This token expires, but the client must not make any assumptions regarding how long the token will remain valid before it does.

If a phone number is provided, SMS-based 2FA is assumed. A successful call to this endpoint will trigger an SMS message containing a TOTP code necessary to complete 2FA setup. These messages are rate limited. If the limit is exceeded, the endpoint will return an error and the ability to send 2FA SMS messages will be locked for a period  of time. Clients must make no assumptions about the number of allowed requests, duration of a lock, or time period  over which they are counted. 

If no phone number is provided, app-based 2FA is used. This endpoint will return a secret and uri the user can use to  configure their TOTP authenticator app. The secret and uri contain the same information - the uri should be used to generate a QR code for the user to scan with an app, and the secret should be displayed for the user to enter manually.

parameters.description: The user is identified through a valid Super Access Token cookie.
parameters.name: SuperAccessToken

parameters.description: Email address to encode in the uri returned for app-based 2FA for accurate labeling within the user's authenticator app. The server does not use this value for any other purpose.
parameters.name: email

parameters.description:
Phone number to use for SMS-based 2FA. This is required for SMS-based 2FA and must be omitted when enabling app-based 2FA.

Maximum Length: 25
parameters.name: phone

parameters.description:
[International calling code](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_country_calling_codes#Alphabetical_listing_by_country_or_region) for the provided phone number. This is required for SMS-based 2FA and should be omitted when enabling app-based 2FA. 

Maximum Length: 3
parameters.name: country

post.description:
This endpoint finishes the 2FA setup flow and enables two-factor authentication for the user.

The caller must provide a state token returned by the PUT variant in addition to a valid TOTP code. This code is either sent via SMS by the PUT variant (SMS-based 2FA), or generated by an  authenticator app configured with the secret or uri returned by the PUT variant (app-based 2FA).

parameters.name: SuperAccessToken

parameters.name: state_token

parameters.description: A TOTP code that corresponds to the state token.
parameters.name: code

parameters.description: If true, Upthere Support is allowed to disable TFA for this user. If false, or omitted, then Upthere Support will not disable TFA for the user if they lose their backup code.
parameters.name: support_can_disable

login_type.description: the user's login type. Possible values are "normal" (TFA not enabled), "app" and "sms".

backup_code.description: The user's backup code. Omitted if the user's does not have TFA enabled.

post.description:
This endpoint disables 2FA for a user. The request can be authenticated with either a valid super access token or a valid challenge token and backup code.

Requests made with invalid backup codes are rate limited per user. If the limit is exceeded, a lock is placed on the ability to check backup codes. No further  requests with backup codes (valid or not) will be accepted for a period of time.  The client must not make assumptions regarding the limit, duration of the lock, or period of time over which attempts are counted. Requests made with super access tokens are not affected by the rate limiter.

If this endpoint returns successfully, the rate limiter state is cleared for 2FA code checks (used in login) and backup code checks (used in this endpoint). Any existing  locks from these rate limiters are unlocked.

parameters.description: The user is identified through a valid Super Access Token cookie. If this is  provided, no backup code or challenge token are needed.
parameters.name: SuperAccessToken

parameters.description: The user's backup code. This is required if no super access token is provided.
parameters.name: backup_code

parameters.description: A valid challenge token obtained from POST /accounts/tokens. This is required if no super access token is provided.
parameters.name: challenge_token

new_user_created.description: A flag to signal that a new user was created during a login request with a grant type of **social_login**. Will be omitted for other grant types.

access_token.description: An access token. On web clients, this is returned in the AccessToken or SuperAccessToken cookie instead.

expires_in.description: Seconds until the access token expires

refresh_token_expires_in.description: Seconds until the refresh token expires. Will be omitted if there is no refresh token.

token_type.description: Either "bearer" or "parley", matching the value provided in the request.

scope.description: List of scopes associated with the access token. This may not be the exactly the same as the scopes requested by the client

refresh_token.description: A refresh token. On web clients, this is returned in the RefreshToken cookie instead. The server may not always return a refresh token with every access token

user_instance_id.description: A shorthand id representing a (device id, client id, user id) combo.

403.description:
Possible messages:
- **access_denied**:
  - User does not exist
  - Incorrect password
  - Invalid challenge token
  - Invalid social token
  - 2FA login attempted but 2FA not enabled
- **invalid_grant**: invalid or expired refresh token or parley token
- **intentional_logout**: refresh requests; indicates refresh token is no longer valid due to intentional logout by user
- **invalid_user_status**: user's status does not allow login (e.g the user is a ghost or unconfirmed user)
- **user_flaggod_for_deletion**: the user is in the process of being deleted and cannot login
- **account_locked**: the password-checking rate limit has been exceeded
- **missing_primary_email**: the social token is not associated with an external account which has primary email
- **user_must_accept_tos**: the user must accept the most recent terms of service to login

reason.description: Reason behind the 2FA challenge. This value is used to inform UI only. Possible values: "user_setting"", "account_locked", "new_device"

challenge_token.description: Challenge token associated with this 2FA challenge.

method.description: Method by which the user should obtain the TOTP code needed for this challenge. This value is used to inform UI only. Possible values: "phone", "app", "email"

Possible messages:
- **invalid_request**:
  - invalid request body
  - invalid parameter
  - requested scope not allowed for client
- **unsupported_response_type**: invalid grant type
- **invalid_code**: invalid 2FA code
- **invalid_referrer_id**: invalid referral code
- **invalid_promotion_code**: invalid promotion code
- **obsolete_api**: api version is obsolete
- **obsolete_sdk**: sdk (framework) version is obsolete
- **obsolete_client**: client version is obsolete

post.description:
This endpoint logs a user in. "Login" is the process of obtaining an access token, which identifies the user to other endpoints.

This endpoint can return the following ways:
- With an access token (status 200, token type = "bearer"). This access token is valid for a period of time (specified in the
  response), after which another access token must be requested. The response may also include
  a refresh token which can be used to obtain a new access token without user involvement, but
  the client must not assume the a refresh token will be returned.
- With a 2FA challenge (status 412). The response will include a challenge token representing a challenge, and
  the client must respond with a valid TOTP 2FA code supplied by the user. Depending on the user's 2FA
  settings, the user obtains the code from their TOTP authenticator app, an SMS sent to them, or
  an email sent to them.
- With a parley token (status 200 and token type = "parley"). This will only occur when the token type field in the request
  is set to "parley". A parley token can be given to another device, which can then exchange the parley token for its own
  refresh token. Parley tokens are single-use and expire after a period of time (specified in the response). The account service
  will accept a parley token multiple times from the client within a short period of time to ensure requests can be replayed, but
  clients must not make assumptions about the length of this time.
- With an error

Requests for access tokens can be authenticated four ways:
- With the user's identifier (email) and password (grant_type="password")
- With a refresh token (grant_type="refresh_token")
- With a challenge token and TOTP 2FA code (grant_type="tfa_code")
- With a parley token (grant_type="parley_token")
- With a social token from a third party identity provider, such as Google or Facebook (grant_type="social_token", grant_type="social_token_login_only")

  Password-based login requests are subject to a rate limit. If too many requests with invalid passwords are made, the account will be temporarily locked and no password-based login requests will be accepted until the lock expires. Other grant types are not affected by this limit or lock. Clients must not make assumptions regarding the limit, the duration of the lock, or the period over which requests are counted. Grant types **social_token** and **social_token_login** have different behavior. Clients should use **social_token** when sending login requests on initial user signup. Login requests for exisiting users should use grant type **social_token_login_only** to authenticate. Grant type **social_token_login_only** will not create a new users and requests will only succeed when the user is in a normal state (e.g. the user is neither a ghost nor uncofirmed).

As this endpoint is the first endpoint most clients contact on startup, it informs clients when they are obsolete through a 400 error and the messages **obsolete_api**, **obsolete_sdk**, and **obsolete_client**.

parameters.description:
Indicates the purpose of the token requested, which affects the type of token that is returned. If omitted, defaults to "bearer".
Allowed values are:
  -  **bearer**:  indicates the token will be used by the device making the request (e.g. return an access token or refresh token directly).
  -  **parley**: indicates the token will be handed off to another device (e.g. return a parley token).

If the parley token type is used, grant_type must be "refresh_token" and the scope must be "generic".
parameters.name: token_type

parameters.description:
Specifies how this login request will be authenticated. This parameter controls which other parameters must be set.
Allowed grant types, and the parameters they require, are:
  - **password**: requires **identifier**, **password**
  - **refresh_token**: requires **refresh_token**
  - **tfa_code**: requires **challenge_token**, **code**
  - **parley_token**: requires **parley_token**
  - **social_token**: requires **identity_provider** and **social_token**
  - **social_token_login_only**: requires **identity_provider** and **social_token**

Additionally, the **scope**, **client_id**, and **device_id** parameters must be set for all grant types.
parameters.name: grant_type

parameters.description:
The access token scope requested. This must be a subset of the scopes allowed for **client_id**. An access token's scope controls what actions can be performed with the token, how long the token lasts until it expires, and whether or not a refresh token is granted with the access token.

Possible scopes are:
- **generic**: all standard actions. If no scope is mentioned in the documentation for an endpoint, this should be assumed.
  This is the default.

- **upload**: allows upload actions including CreateDocOp, PartialPayloadClientOp, PayloadCompleteOp, MergeOp.
- **super**: allows access to account settings endpoints. *password* grant type only. This may be requested alongside
  generic in a single token.

- **readdoc**: allows read-only access to a single doc. *refresh_token* grant type only.
  Must be requested in the format 'readdoc,b=x&d=y&v=z', where x,y, and z are hex-encoded branch, doc and view ids.
parameters.name: scope

parameters.description: The client ID of the client making the request
parameters.name: client_id

parameters.description: The device ID of the device making the request. If possible, this should be a 256-bit hash of a system-provided device identifier. If that is not possible, this should be a random 256-bit number stored in persistant storage and reused in future requests.
parameters.name: device_id

parameters.description: An identifier identifying the user to login. This must be the email address associated with the user's account. Required for the **password** grant type only.
parameters.name: identifier

parameters.description: The password associated with the user's account. Required for the **password** grant type only.
parameters.name: password

parameters.description: A valid refresh token returned by a prior call to this endpoint. Required for the **refresh_token** grant type only.
parameters.name: refresh_token

parameters.description: A challenge token returned by a prior call to this endpoint. Required for the **tfa_code** grant type only.
parameters.name: challenge_token

parameters.description: A valid TOTP 2FA code associated with the challenge token. This must be obtained from the user's TOTP authenticator app (if app 2FA is enabled) or from an SMS sent to their phone (if SMS 2FA is enabled). Required for the **tfa_code** grant type only.
parameters.name: code

parameters.description: An identity provider associated with the social token which identifies the user to login. Required for the **social_token** and **social_token_login_only** grant types only.
parameters.name: identity_provider

parameters.description: The social token identifying the user to login. Required for the **social_token** and **social_token_login_only** grant types only.
parameters.name: social_token

parameters.description: The parley token to exchange for a refresh token. Required for the **parley_token** grant type only.
parameters.name: parley_token

parameters.description: The referral code of the referrer which refers the user to login. Optional for the **social_token** and **social_token_login_only** grant types only.
parameters.name: referrer_id

parameters.description: The promotion code the user applied to login. Optional for the **social_token** and **social_token_login_only** grant types only.
parameters.name: promotion_code

parameters.description: Indicates the marketing affiliate with the user. e.g. WD, Sandisk. This is restricted to 100 characters. Optional for the **social_token** and **social_token_login_only** grant types only.
parameters.name: affiliate

parameters.description: Indicates the signup source where the created user was initiated. Ex: Share, Organic, Waitlist etc. This is restricted to 100 characters. Optional for the **social_token** and **social_token_login_only** grant types only.
parameters.name: source

parameters.description: A flag to indicate wether or not the user has accepted the terms of service presented by the client on login.
parameters.name: tos_was_accepted

delete.description:
This endpoint logs a user out by invalidating a refresh token. For web clients, this clears all token-related cookies as well.
This can be used for self-logout or remote logout. In self-logout, a client requests that its own refresh token be invalidated. A refresh token is required for this request. In remote-logout, a client requests that another client by logged out. This requires a super access token.
If the device is a registered with the backend (such as Skyline), it is deregistered during logout.

parameters.description: Authentication access token (Base64 encoded), Super scope required. Not necessary for self logout.
parameters.name: X-Upthere-At

parameters.description: The refresh token to invalidate. For self-logout, either this or the **refresh_token** body parameter must be provided. Not necessary for remote logout.
parameters.name: RefreshToken

parameters.description: The refresh token to invalidate. Either this or the **RefreshToken** cookie must be provided.
parameters.name: refresh_token

parameters.description: The client ID associated with the refresh token.
parameters.name: client_id

parameters.description: The device ID associated with the refresh token.
parameters.name: device_id

scopes.description: The scopes of the token passed in the X-Upthere-At header

user_id.description: The user ID of the token passed in the X-Upthere-At header

expires_at.description: The expiration date of the token passed in the X-Upthere-At header

put.description:
This endpoint initiates the direct signup flow and creates an unconfirmed user. Unconfirmed users must confirm their accounts before they can login.

It triggers a confirmation email to the new user containing a confirmation code. This code must be passed to the POST variant of this endpoint to confirm the user and complete the signup. The code can expire, but the client must not make any assumptions regarding the lifetime of the code.

It is not an error to call this endpoint on a user that already exists but has not yet confirmed their account with a call to POST /accounts/users or PUT /accounts/ghosts. The parameters submitted here overwrite any existing values for the user. This endpoint returns an error if the user has already confirmed their account. This endpoint is subject to backend limits on signups. A 300 error is returned if signups are closed.

post.description:
The request body should contain either a stream of standard MsgPack objects or a multipart form-data of JSON objects, that follow the op entry definitions. If a multipart/form-data request is made, the operation type must be supplied in each part header "X-Upthere-Otype" and the part must be of type "application/json". Payload operations in a multipart request must be made with a JSON part and immediately followed by their corresponding payload part with a "Content-Type" header of "application/octet-stream". OpIDs and 256-bit seeds are passed as hex strings for all multipart/form-data requests. The gateway will add the User ID extracted from the auth token header to each of the provided operations before appending to the Opqueue.

Any error that is returned may include a header "X-Upthere-Last", which contains the operation ID for the last successfully queued operation. This operation and any before it in the request do not need to be retransmitted. If an error is reported and this header is unset, no operations in the batch succeeded.

[Ops definitions](https://git.corp.upthere.com/backend/upcode/blob/master/src/services/lib/entry/ops.go)

get.description:
This endpoint returns a list of public keys that are pairs of the private keys  identity service used to sign JWTs. Although this endpoint currently only returns a single RSA public key, but it's important to assume this endponit might return more JWKs in the future for the purpose of rotating signing keys.
The keys returned by this endpoint is all base64 url encoded. It follows the standard jwks format. A good example can be found here https://auth0.com/docs/tokens/reference/jwt/jwks-properties and here https://www.googleapis.com/oauth2/v3/certs.
Clients can use this endpoint to get the public keys then use this public key to verify the signature of the JWTs client receives. One example of using this key is when client receives an access token in JWT format and decode the claims from JWT, but isn't sure that there is no middle man modifying the claim. Then to assure this, client can use the keys returned by this endpoint, to verify the signature from JWTs.
get.summary: Return a list of keys that identity service used to sign JWTs.

post.description:
This end point resets a user's password. There are two stages:

In the first stage, the user provides their email address and we send them an email with a token.

In the second stage, the user provides the token and the new password, and we check the token and change the password if it is valid.

post.description:
This endpoint initiates the direct signup flow and creates an unconfirmed user. Unconfirmed users must confirm their accounts before they can login.

It triggers a confirmation email to the new user containing a confirmation token. This token must be passed to the POST to /identity/signup/confirm endpoint to confirm the user and complete the signup. The token can expire, but the client must not make any assumptions regarding the lifetime of the token.

It returns error if the email is already signed up by another user including marked for deletion users. It also returns error if the provided user agent refers to an obsolete client or SDK

post.description:
This endpoint implements OAuth2 flows.

- **Resource Owner Flow (Password Flow)**:
  The user enters their username and password into the client directly.
  This is the flow used by first-party clients.


  This includes the following request parameters:
    - grant_type (required): password
    - username (required)
    - password (required)
    - client_id (required)
    - client_secret
    - scope


  Reponse parameters:
    - access_token
    - refresh_token
    - id_token
    - token_type
    - expires_in
    - scope

- **Refresh Flow**:
  The client exchanges a refresh token for another access and refresh token.
  Note that this flow does not invalidates the refresh token in the request immediately,
  the refresh token will be invalidated when the refresh token in response is used (in next refresh flow)
  It is recommended to use new refresh token each time.


  This includes the following request parameters:
    - grant_type (required): refresh_token
    - refresh_token (required)
    - client_id (required)
    - client_secret
    - device_id
    - tos_was_accepted


  Reponse parameters:
    - access_token
    - refresh_token
    - id_token
    - token_type
    - expires_in
    - scope

- **Obtain Parley Token Flow (Custom)**:
  The client can exchange their refresh token for a parley token, which can be used to obtain another access
  and refresh token. They’re expected to be used in the following scenarios:
    - Auotmatically login during signup:
      A parley token is returned from the signup endpoint.
      This token can be used to automatically log the user in once they’re confirmed.
    - Bootstrap a login session on another device:
      If the user is using Client A, which wants to log the user into Client B (maybe a hardware device),
      client A requests a parley token and passes it to client B, which then exchanges the parley token
      for its own access and refresh tokens. This ensures both clients have separate login sessions.


  This includes the following request parameters:
    - grant_type (required): upthere_obtain_parley
    - refresh_token (required)
    - client_id (required)
    - client_secret


  Reponse parameters:
    - parley_token
    - token_type
    - expires_in
    - scope

- **Exchange Parley Token Flow (Custom)**:
  A client exchanges a parley token for an access and refresh token. A parley token can be used only once.


  This includes the following request parameters:
    - grant_type (required): upthere_exchange_parley
    - parley_token (required)
    - client_id (required)
    - client_secret
    - device_id
    - scope


  Reponse parameters:
    - access_token
    - refresh_token
    - id_token
    - token_type
    - expires_in
    - scope


In lieu of the client_id and client_secret body parameters, these values can be passed through the HTTP Basic Auth header.

parameters.description:
- password: Resource Owner Flow.

- refresh_token: Refresh Flow.

- upthere_obtain_parley: Obtain Parley Token Flow.

- upthere_exchange_parley: Exchange Parley Token Flow.

post.description:
This end point is the logout endpoint, allowing clients to revoke refresh tokens.

It can be used in either "self-logout" or remote logout scenarios:

For self-logout, the request should contain a refresh token and that refresh token will be revoked. Authorization header is not needed if refresh token is provided. If token is not valid, no error is returned. Self-logout does not require authorization (access token).
For remote-logout, the request should be authenticated with a super access token and contain a client ID (optional) and a device ID (optional). If the device ID is included, the provided (client ID, device ID) pair will be logged out; if only a client id is provided, all devices associated with that client will be logged out; otherwise all devices of the user will be logged out. Remote-logout requires the token has scope "identity.super"
Revoke API does not return errors for properly formed but invalid client id or device id.

parameters.description:
Includes access token in the header for authorization, token type should be included too.

For example, "Bearer Rkmqo2UkEIyIBCrtro1QpIG" indicates header: "Authorization: Bearer Rkmqo2UkEIyIBCrtro1QpIG"
parameters.name: Authorization

parameters.description: The refresh token to revoke. This is required for self-logout.
parameters.name: refresh_token

parameters.description: The client ID of the client to logout. This is used for remote logout. If this is omitted, all instances of the user are logged out.
parameters.name: client_id

parameters.description: The device ID of the client to logout. If this is omitted, all instances associated with the client ID are logged out. If this is included, only the provided (client id, device id) combination is logged out.
parameters.name: device_id

get.description:
This endpoint returns user information, including users in all status like mark deleted, unconfirmed, or ghost.

An access token with scope of "upthere.read", "identity.prefs", or "ideneity.super" is required. It returns all fields or certain fields in result according to the scope.

Fields for scope identity.super:
  - user_id
  - status
  - email
  - profile
  - tos_was_accepted
  - accepted_tos_version
  - accepted_tos_version_change_at
  - analytics_opt_in
  - analytics_opt_in_changed_at
  - marketing_opt_in
  - marketing_opt_in_changed_at
  - created_at
  - confirmed_at
  - trashed_at
  - should_delete_at


Fields for scope upthere.read:
  - status
  - email
  - profile
  - tos_was_accepted
  - accepted_tos_version_change_at
  - created_at
  - confirmed_at
  - trashed_at
  - should_delete_at


Fields for scope identity.prefs:
  - analytics_opt_in
  - analytics_opt_in_changed_at
  - marketing_opt_in
  - marketing_opt_in_changed_at

200.description: Success - a stream of search result objects will be streamed back over chunked encoding.

parameters.description: Authentication access token (Base64 encoded)
parameters.name: X-Upthere-At

parameters.description: Responses will be returned in an array rather than a stream if set to something truthy
parameters.name: nostream

parameters.description: A Map of string <query_id> to query object.
parameters.name: queries

post.description:
Query takes a map of QID (string) to query object and returns a stream of search result objects for each query. If JSON, these will be new-line separated. A query which has 0 results will return 1 result item with the "qid" plus "last" and "complete" marked true but no value. the query parameter "nostream" allows clients to request the results as an array rather than a stream. Will return aggregation buckets corresponding to missing values unless prevented with a match predicate.
QueryHandlerAD differs from QueryHandlerAC only in that it may take a {ViewID^[]} predicate to direct the query at multiple views simultaneously. Such a request will contain result objects for documents in each view that contain it. Limit applies to the number of document objects returned. So-called Multi-view queries are only valid for head of branches and are not valid with aggregations.

ctx.description: The UploadContextV1 for this document upload

body.description: The content of this comment, nil if this is a delete comment response

branch_id.description: ID of the branch that this comment belongs to, nil if the comment is a view comment

user_id.description: ID of the user who made this comment

view_id.description: ID of the view that this comment belongs to

doc_id.description: ID of the doc that this comment belongs to, nil if the comment is a view comment

created_at.description: Type-1 UUID (in hex form) which represents the time when this comment was made

locale.description: locale of the user, BCP47 standard, default to en-US if not provided.

country.description: Two-letter (ISO Alpha-2) country code of the user's country.

uiid.description: The User Instance ID of the user instance

uiname.description: The display name of the user instance

branch_id.description: ID of the branch that this comment belongs to

from.description: Type-1 UUID (in hex form) which represents the time start retrieving the comments from. An empty value means start from the latest one. Since the api only allows retrieving comments in reverse chronologic order, all the comments returned will be dated before this time.

doc_locator.description: Locator associated with the document. An empty value means the document is located in the current data center.

view_id.description: ID of the view that this comment belongs to

view_locator.description: Locator associated with the view. An empty value means the view is located in the current data center.

to.description: Type-1 UUID (in hex form) which represents the time to stop retrieving the comments. Note that if there is comment created exactly at <to> timestamp, it will not be included. Combined with <from> parameter, this will construct a query time range. And the result will include comment in <from> but exclude comment in <to>.

limit.description: The maximum number of comments returned, default value is 100. The maximum limit can be 10000

doc_id.description: ID of the doc that this comment belongs to

jpeg_text_md.description: if true, the "TextMD" preview will be returned if available

get_text.description: if true, the "Text" preview will be returned if available

category.description: Type category of the document revision

branch_id.description: Branch ID of the document revision

doc_id.description: Document ID of the document revision

doc_owner_id.description: The User ID of the owner of the document

rev_id.description: Revision ID of the document revision

created_at.description: Time the view was created. In json Hex-encoded type-1 UUID

view_locator.description: The locator string of the view ID for multidatacenter support. This is currently only returned in the v1000 endpoint

asof.description: Time the view was lasted updated. In json Hex-encoded type-1 UUID

items.description: List of user ids that belong to this view.

asof.description: Time of the most recent value in the result set. Hex-encoded type-1 UUID

name.description: Name of the directory. May be empty only for root directory.

updated_at.description: time at which the last updated occurred.

has_ever_canceled.description: indicates whether the user has ever completely canceled their account.

account_size.description: size of the user's account in bytes, not taking promotions into consideration

is_subscribed.description: indicates the user is subscribed. If this is set, the subscription field will contain the details of the user's subscription. This will be set even if the user is still in their trial period but has elected to subscribe.

quota.description: the user's quota in bytes. -1 if their quota is unlimited.

trial_end_at.description: the end date of the user's trial

cc_last4.description: The last 4 digits of the user's default payment source

estimated_price.description: an estimate of the price (in cents) the user will pay next billing period based on their current effective usage and plans. If the user is not currently subscribed, this represents what they would pay if they were to subscribe.

promotion_end_at.description: the end date of all promotions applied to the user's account

cc_exp_month.description: The expiration month of the user's default payment source

subscription.description: The user's subscription. This is not included if the user has no subscription or their subscription has been deactivated.

data_kept_until.description: The date until which we promise to keep the user's data

cc_brand.description: The brand of the user's default payment source

is_canceling.description: indicates the user's subscription is canceling. This will remain set until the end of their current billing period, at which point their subscription will be deactivated.

cc_exp_year.description: The expiration year of the user's default payment source

is_trialing.description: indicates the user is in a trial. A trialing user may or may not also be subscribed.

effective_account_size.description: size of the user's account in bytes after subtracting credits from promotions

state.description: The state of the subscription: -1 (deactivated), 0 (invalid), 100 (active), or 300 (payment failed) (see [billing.go](http://git.corp.upthere.com/backend/upcode/blob/master/src/services/lib/updb/billing.go))

payment_failed_at.description: The date/time at which payment failed for this subscription

incr_plan_id.description: The plan id of the user's incremental plan

payment_failed_reason.description: The reason payment failed, provided by Stripe (https://stripe.com/docs/api#errors)

started_at.description: The date/time at which this subscription started

fixed_plan_id.description: The plan id of the user's fixed plan

current_period_end.description: The date/time at which the current period ends for this subscription

buckets.description: Buckets will be streamed back using chunked encoding over HTTP. JSON results will be newline separated. In the case of a match they will be sorted by score, otherwise they will be sorted by the value they represent.

branch_id.description: the branch_id of the preview requested

view_id.description: the view_id of the preview requested

doc_id.description: the doc_id of the preview requested

key.description: the key of the preview requested

rev_id.description: the rev_id of the preview requested

foo.description: Type-1 UUID (in hex form) which represents the time when a comment was created
Type-1 UUID (in hex form) which represents the time when a comment was created
